properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and blowing snow over Northwestern Quebec... The snow will continue through Wednesday morning. Total snowfall amounts ranging from 10 to 20 centimetres are expected. In addition, strong northwesterly winds developing Tuesday will give blowing snow causing significantly reduced visibility over exposed areas. As a result, poor driving conditions are expected. Conditions will improve gradually on Wednesday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-22T05:14:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-21T13:15:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3884773302.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Late season snowfall with some blowing snow continue tonight. Snow, heavy at times, is expected to continue tonight as a low pressure system moves through. An additional 5 to 10 cm of snow will fall before the snow tapers off to scattered flurries overnight. In addition, strong northerly wind gusts up to 60 km/h combining with falling snow and blowing snow will produce very low visibilities. Hazardous winter travelling conditions are expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-21T16:59:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-21T01:37:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2017653292.2020
Area: Webequie, Fort Hope - Lansdowne House - Ogoki
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Cold Arctic air returns with strong and gusty west winds. West winds with frequent gusts of 70 km/h will occur today in the wake of a sharp arctic cold front that blasted across the region this morning. A few gusts to 80 km/h are possible this afternoon. These winds are strong enough to cause Isolated power outages. Winds will slowly diminish this evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-22T03:59:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-21T15:40:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0735116467.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Late season snow with blowing snow on tap. Snow associated with a low pressure system will fall across areas near James Bay tonight, then taper off to scattered flurries from northwest to southeast over all areas except Moosonee on Tuesday. Snow will taper off over Moosonee Tuesday night. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are likely across the region. In addition, strong northerly wind gusts up near 70 and possibly 80 km/h combining with falling and occasional blowing snow will produce very low visibilities especially Tuesday. Hazardous winter travelling conditions are expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-21T17:37:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-21T01:38:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0874954561.2020
Area: Attawapiskat, Fort Albany, Moosonee
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:

In addition, strong northerly wind gusts up near 70 and possibly 80 km/h combining with falling and occasional blowing snow will produce very low visibilities at times today. Hazardous winter travelling conditions are expected. Snow will gradually taper off to scattered flurries tonight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant spring snow expected tonight and Wednesday. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 40 km/h. Locations: northwestern New Brunswick. Time span: this evening until late Wednesday. Remarks: Snow, heavy at times, is expected to develop this evening over northwestern New Brunswick and persist overnight and Wednesday, then taper to flurries Wednesday evening. The snow will be wet and may be mixed occasionally with rain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Update To Civil Emergency Alert Issued By Government Of Saskatchewan
properties.Summary:
Description: Update for the Civil Emergency Alert issued by the Government of Saskatchewan. The state of emergency in Saskatchewan has been extended. Keep following the orders of the Chief Medical Health Officer. Practice physical distancing. Avoid gatherings with people outside your immediate household. Avoid unnecessary travel. Self-isolate if returning from foreign travel or if experiencing any symptoms. Wash your hands often. Together, we are reducing the risk. We can pull together by staying apart.
Expires: 2020-04-27T17:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre, 2020-04-20T15:52:24-06:00, DB0F89B8-9E73-E7EC-53B5-F6D10DA2BBD7
Area: Province of Saskatchewan
properties.Author: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow is expected Wednesday... Snow will begin Tuesday evening or overnight and intensify Wednesday morning. Snow at times heavy will taper off Wednesday night or Thursday morning. Total snowfall amounts in excess of 15 centimetres are expected. A brief period of rain is also possible over the Chaleur Bay Area Wednesday afternoon. Quickly accumulating snow and low visibility will give difficult road conditions. The accumulated snow will be wet and heavy, which could significantly weight down tree branches and certain structures. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-21T18:18:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-21T02:19:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4051088262.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Late season snowfall with occasional blowing snow continues today. Snow will continue today as the low moves slowly into Western Quebec. An additional 2 to 5 cm of snow is likely with locally higher amounts of 5 to 10 cm possible near the Quebec border by this evening. Strong and gusty northwesterly winds will result in low visibility at times in blowing snow. Motorists should be prepared for poor winter driving conditions. Snow will taper off to scattered flurries along with slowly diminishing winds this evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-22T05:59:14-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A variety of wintry precipitation is expected. Locations: Avalon Peninsula. Time span: continuing until this evening. Total rainfall: less than 2 mm (northwestern Avalon) to 20 mm (parts of the southeastern Avalon). Total snowfall: less than 2 cm (southeastern Avalon) to 10 cm (parts of the northern Avalon). Remarks: Precipitation has begun over most of the Avalon Peninsula. Over southeastern parts of the peninsula, the precipitation will remain mostly as rain, while over northwestern areas, mainly snow is expected. Areas in between, including the St. John's Metro area, can expect a messy variety of rain, freezing rain, ice pellets, and snow. There is potential for localized significant snowfall, especially across higher elevations on the northern Avalon. Conditions will improve this evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-04-22T00:59:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-21T13:16:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2632157507.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest
properties.Author: Environment Canada
